text: Frankie Manning (May 26, 1914 â€“ April 27, 2009) was an American dancer, choreographer and instructor. He helped develop the Lindy Hop, an American dance from Harlem, New York City. At age 75, Manning received a 1989 Tony Award for co-choreographing Black and Blue, a musical on Broadway. Manning wrote an autobiography, Frankie Manning: Ambassador of Lindy Hop. Manning was born in Jacksonville, Florida. He died at age 94 in Manhattan, New York City. ==References== Category:People from New York City Category:American dancers Category:American choreographers Category:1914 births Category:Tony Award winners
title: Frankie Manning
